data.title: Add 'Reason' to SelectionChangeEvent
data.body:
In the process of working on a [Vim plugin for VSCode](https://github.com/VSCodeVim/Vim) I've run into a number of areas where I need a little bit of API help. Apologies if any of my suggestions already exist!

One thing that I would really like is an `onClick` event. I know that we have a way to see if selections are changed, but the difficulty is that the Vim plugin changes the selections a lot, which makes it difficult to know _who_ changed the selections - me or you. `onClick` would solve this problem.

data.title: Improve TypeScript syntax highlighting
data.body:
Version 1.2.1
Commit fe7f407b95b7f78405846188259504b34ef72761
Date 2016-06-14T13:00:22.146Z
Shell 0.37.6
Renderer 49.0.2623.75
Node 5.10.0

Windows 7 x64

Here's a side by side comparison of the (almost) same sample code from the TypeScript playground.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/412489/16328521/7735c9b6-39b1-11e6-8a86-cab3423d02be.png)

As you can see the TypeScript side doesn't highlight function/method calls in green as the JavaScript side does.

It's not easy to go through a big white-colored block like this. Specially for people new to TypeScript.
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/412489/16331587/a79ec07e-39c7-11e6-81c8-4b890840712a.png)

data.title: "Open Symbol By Name" is not working properly in multipy typescript projects.
data.body:
- VSCode Version:1.2.1
- OS Version: windows 8.1

Steps to Reproduce:
1. create a project like:

```
a/a.ts
a/tsconfig.json   => files:["a.ts"]
b/b.ts
b/tsconfig.json   => files:["b.ts"]
c.ts
```
1. Ctrl+P and type "#" to search some symbols in "a.ts" "b.ts" or "c.ts". You will expect they will be seached. But the search result is depend on which file is currently opening or something else maybe open file order.

For exmaple:
open "c.ts" and insert:

```
import "./b.ts"
```

Then you can search symbols in "b.ts". Then comment it, and if symbols in "b.ts" can be searched is undetermined, sometime can and sometime can't.

And in my another project, only symbols in ".d.ts" can be searched.

And another problem is I can't search variable names in global scope, even I export it.

data.title: Allow extensions to run custom terminals
data.body:
For the [julia](https://github.com/JuliaEditorSupport/julia-vscode) extension, I'd like to be able to add a julia terminal to VS code so that we could have the julia REPL inside VS code.

I think this could be pretty simple: essentially my extension would just need some way to tell VS code that it should add one more terminal window, and allow me to specify a command line that starts that julia terminal.

Bonus points would be if I could for example start that terminal in a hidden state, so the julia process would start, the output would already be captured by the terminal, but the panel would not be visible. And the maybe provide an API that allows my extension to toggle the visibility of the panel, or something like that.

data.title: VSCode should only reset breakpoints after save when already debugging
data.body:
Here's a proposal for debugAdapters to support Edit on Idle, Edit and Continue scenarios.

Only reset the breakpoints after the file has been saved rather than every keystroke.

Notify the debugAdapter with an extra afterEdit:true arg in setBreakpoints

The debugAdapter can then asynchronously come back when it the new edited code is all mapped.

data.title: Code does not prompt for restart when installing a .vsix file.
data.body:

```
Version 1.3.0-insider
Commit 5eaf9f05038b0a9818ebff510e1aafe07ac1ae68
Date 2016-06-23T05:07:59.360Z
Shell 0.37.6
Renderer 49.0.2623.75
Node 5.10.0
```
- OS Version:

```
OS Name Microsoft Windows 10 Enterprise
Version 10.0.10586 Build 10586
```

Steps to Reproduce:
1. From new extension UI, search for any extension and install

Expected Behavior:
Code installs extension and prompts for restart.

Actual Behavior:
Code installs extension and does not prompt for restart.

data.title: UI and UX overhaul

milestone.title: On Deck
milestone.description:
The Issues assigned to the **On Deck** milestone under consideration for the upcoming milestones.
Our goal is to always have less than 100 Issues on deck.

data.body:
The VS Code UI and UX has evolved to a point where we need to take a holistic and top down view on the experience and look for improvements and inconsistencies. We should define our principles and design language and use that to evolve the product.

In particular, we need to focus on 
- iconography #8017
- panels #7161
- colours #7649, #7648
- commanding #1136

data.title: Error
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2
- OS Version: Linux Mint 17.3(Ubuntu Based 14.04.04)

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Install all plugins for Haskell and haskell-platform 7.6.3-10.
2. Create one simple file. Ex.: 
-- File add.hs
myNot False = True
myNot True = False
sumList (x:xs) = x + sumList xs
sumList [] = 0
3. Configure informations for file in launch.json
{
    "version": "0.2.0",
    "configurations": [
        {
            "type": "ghc",
            "name": "ghci debug viewer Phoityne",
            "request": "launch",
            "internalConsoleOptions": "openOnSessionStart",
            "workspace": "${workspaceRoot}",
            "startup": "${workspaceRoot}/HaskellLearning/src/learning/add.hs",
            "logFile": "${workspaceRoot}/.vscode/phoityne.log",
            "logLevel": "WARNING",
            "ghciPrompt": "H>>= ",
            "ghciCmd": "cabal ghci --test --no-load --no-build"
        }
    ]
}
4. Entry on Debug view and execute.
5. Error: 
phoityne-vscode.exe is not found. Run `stack install phoityne-vscode`, and put it to PATH environment.

Detail I have installed cabal not stack and exists other error that starting vscode says:
Couldn't start ghc-mod process Error: Command failed: ghc-mod version.

data.title: Make snippet selection case sensitive

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.1
- OS Version: Wind10

I just added latex snippets to the [julia](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=julialang.language-julia) extension. These snippets essentially map things like `\eta` onto `η`. This is very hand for scientific code.

One problem is that we will have snippets like `\eta` and `\Eta`, where the lower case will translate to the lower case greek letter and the upper case version to the upper case greek letter. But the snippet filtering right now is not case sensitive: when I enter `\Eta`, it will select `\eta` as the default and show `\Eta` as the second item in the list.

I think the best solution here would be this:
1. if there is a case-sensitive match, select that by default
2. If not, select a case-insensitive match as the default

data.title: experimentalDecorators Typescript warning always present
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.0-insider
- OS Version: El Capitan

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create a Typescript project
2. Use decorators (I am using [Mobx](https://mobxjs.github.io/mobx/best/syntax.html))  

I keep seeing the warning:  

```
[ts] Experimental suport for decorators is a feature that is subject to chang in a future release. Set the 'experimentalDecoratos' option to remove this warning.
```

Where should I set this option? Because my tsconfig.json should be right  

```
{
  "compilerOptions": {
    "target": "es5",
    "module": "commonjs",
    "declaration": false,
    "noImplicitAny": false,
    "removeComments": false,
    "isolatedModules": false,
    "jsx": "react",
    "experimentalDecorators": true,
    "emitDecoratorMetadata": true,
    "noLib": false,
    "preserveConstEnums": true,
    "suppressImplicitAnyIndexErrors": true,
    "outDir": "./dist/"
  },
  "exclude": [
    "client",
    "node_modules",
    "typings/browser",
    "typings/browser.d.ts"
  ]
}
```

data.title: [json] hover in JSON documents hides '*'
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.1
- VSCode C++ extension Version: 0.7.0
- OS Version: Windows 10 Enterprise

NOTE: You need the C++ extension version 0.7.0 or later because we introduced the c_cpp_properties.json schema file.

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open any folder containing a .cpp file with unresolved header files.
2. Click on the lightbulb for an unresolved header and select the "Add include path to settings"
   3.The c_cpp_properties.json file opens. Save once so intellisense works (see issue 8067 for more details).
3. Hovering to see a description over "includePath" the '_' character is not visible. But if you start typing "includePath" the intellisense shows the '_' character. See the two attached screenshots for more info.
   ![image1](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/19478941/16315443/06268208-391e-11e6-88b8-f7eb12e4b956.png)
   ![image2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/19478941/16315442/0623315c-391e-11e6-88b8-7a27fb880d55.png)

data.title: JSON schema file doesn't provide intellisense until the initial save of a .json file
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.1
- VSCode C++ extension Version: 0.7.0
- OS Version: Windows 10 Enterprise

NOTE: You need the C++ extension version 0.7.0 or later because we introduced the c_cpp_properties.json schema file.

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open any folder containing a .cpp file with unresolved header files.
2. Click on the lightbulb for an unresolved header and select the "Add include path to settings"
3. The c_cpp_properties.json file opens, but no intellisense is available. After I save once, intellisense begins to work.

data.title: Create test for this method

data.body: I'm not sure if this is the right place to ask or if there is existing solution for that, but after few hours of googling I was not able to find it.
